Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is about to cross the street without looking for oncoming traffic.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They are expected to attend every service and take part in church community activities consistently
Story: I stood at the corner, clutching my Bible, glancing at my watch. The church service was about to start, and I knew how important it was to be there—my pastor always said our presence was a sign of faith and commitment. But then I saw my stepbrother, Ethan, darting ahead, headphones in, about to cross the busy street without even glancing up. My heart pounded. As his step-sibling, I was supposed to look out for him, make sure he was safe, especially since Mom always reminded me that he looked up to me. But if I stopped him, I’d be late for church—again. I could already hear the disappointment in my youth leader’s voice, the subtle reminders about priorities and setting an example. I felt torn, rooted to the spot, watching Ethan’s oblivious figure and the ticking clock, the weight of both expectations pressing down on me.
